text: I like the goal you set. I also think it would be worthwhile to pick one issue at a time, and ideally also pick a specific problem that you would like to solve.

elements.text: I like the goal you set. I also think it would be worthwhile to pick one issue at a time, and ideally also pick a specific problem that you would like to solve.

text: Exploration is always interesting, but without focusing on a specific problem, the risk is that it remains only interesting without becoming useful. Focusing on a problem instead helps you guide your design decisions.

elements.text: Exploration is always interesting, but without focusing on a specific problem, the risk is that it remains only interesting without becoming useful. Focusing on a problem instead helps you guide your design decisions.

text: Yeah need to correct the links to the demo so they don’t use SSL. Just change https:// to http:// in the URL and it’ll work.

elements.text: Yeah need to correct the links to the demo so they don’t use SSL. Just change https:// to http:// in the URL and it’ll work.

text: But it depends on the version of SnS whether that error matters or not. There’s two branches of development at the moment. “Bidirectional” SnS, which is described in the SPLASH 2018 paper, doesn’t use the external solver so the error above doesn’t matter. The “v0.7.1" link is this “Bidirectional” SnS. “Bidirectional” SnS is better formalized and can operate on larger programs but can currently only perform “small” program changes (i.e. modification of literal strings, numbers, or lists). The other SnS branch, call it “Output-Directed” SnS, can perform larger program transformations and is what was demoed at the LIVE workshop (<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9JcKnJyufD8>). It’s available through the “icfp-2018-svg” link. Let me know if you have any questions.

attachments.title: LIVE 2018: SVG Programming By Direct Manipulation of Intermediates
attachments.fallback: YouTube Video: LIVE 2018: SVG Programming By Direct Manipulation of Intermediates

There’s two branches of development at the moment. “Bidirectional” SnS, which is described in the SPLASH 2018 paper, doesn’t use the external solver so the error above doesn’t matter. The “v0.7.1" link is this “Bidirectional” SnS. “Bidirectional” SnS is better formalized and can operate on larger programs but can currently only perform “small” program changes (i.e. modification of literal strings, numbers, or lists). The other SnS branch, call it “Output-Directed” SnS, can perform larger program transformations and is what was demoed at the LIVE workshop (
). It’s available through the “icfp-2018-svg” link. Let me know if you have any questions.
